column4: I have a file in my system root named vmlinuz, would this be a remnant of my attempting to install GRUB? I don't recall seeing at before.
it's probably a symlink and it should be there
He doesn't need to sudo -i unless he'll be running multiple commands. Just prepending sudo would do
I see, but he's using a pipe
I don't think the command after the pipe will have root rights...
He doesn't need to sudo -i unless he'll be running multiple commands. Just prepending sudo would do
llutz nope... :D
llutz wrong assumption :P
||arifaX : 700 would make it inaccessible to anyone apart from the owner
||arifaX exactly what I would like!!!!
Certainly good if you don't want anyone finding your stuff. I don't store anything in my home directory anyway, so it'd be a waste for me to do that (apart from settings which go there)
why don't you store anything in your homedir?
that's it purpose right! Always handy to know: if I backup my homedir, I've got all my stuff :-)
I have a secondary hard drive for all my data stuff; downloads, schoolwork, music and so on.
I see! I must admit I have a secondary filesystem as well, mounted on /data, owned by tvl:tvl and chmod 700 :P
I could set myself as just the owner of that drive, I suppose, as no one else actually has to access this computer.
that's a good practice if you ask me... sooner or later you will give someone an ftp account, and all stuff will be visible...

I don't need FTP to my personal computer. Although I've set up FTP on a VPS I own and taken the precaution of making the account they use unable to use sudo and the FTP is locked into their home directory.

that's good, also good to set the shell: /bin/false. Only thing I wanted to say was: requirements change. You can't predict the future... If you make it as tight as possible from the beginning, you will most likely run into less problems in the future :-)
What's would setting it to /bin/false do?
you're ftp user cannot logon using ssh

Oh, thought it might be that. I need them to be able to though to restart certain things if the server is rebooted for whatever reason and I'm not available. Is there an option to lock their shell into their home directory as well?
because it will not get a shell. I've even put the 'AllowUsers tvl' on my private server
AllowUsers is from ssh.... I have no experience of chrooting users to their homedir using ssh, but a quick google showed that there are a lot of posts/howto's about it
